sentences.sentence: Digory had hardly ever seen anyone so surprised and offended( 被冒犯的 ) as his Uncle did at this simple question.
“Me? Me?” he exclaimed( 惊叫 ).
“The boy must be mad! A man at my time of life, and in my state of health, to risk the shock and the dangers of being flung( 猛扔 ) suddenly into a different universe?
I never heard anything so preposterous( 荒谬的 ) in my life!
Do you realize what you’re saying?
Think what Another World means—you might meet anything—anything.”
“And I suppose you’ve sent Polly into it then,” said Digory. His cheeks were flaming with anger now.
“And all I can say,” he added, “even if you are my Uncle—is that you’ve behaved like a coward( 胆小鬼 ), sending a girl to a place you’re afraid to go to yourself.”
“Silence, sir!” said Uncle Andrew, bringing his hand down on the table.
“I will not be talked to like that by a little, dirty, schoolboy.
You don’t understand. I am the great scholar( 学者 ), the magician, the adept( 专家 ), who is doing the experiment.
Of course I need subjects( 实验对象 ) to do it on.
Bless my soul( 天哪 ), you’ll be telling me next that I ought to have asked the guinea-pigs( 豚鼠 )’ permission before I used them!
No great wisdom can be reached without sacrifice( 牺牲 ).
But the idea of my going myself is ridiculous( 荒谬的 ).
It’s like asking a general to fight as a common soldier.
Supposing I got killed, what would become of my life’s work?”
“Oh, do stop jawing( 说教 ),” said Digory. “Are you going to bring Polly back?”
“I was going to tell you, when you so rudely interrupted me,” said Uncle Andrew,
“that I did at last find out a way of doing the return journey. The green rings draw you back.”
“But Polly hasn’t got a green ring.”
“No,” said Uncle Andrew with a cruel smile.
“Then she can’t get back,” shouted Digory. “And it’s exactly the same as if you’d murdered her.
“She can get back,” said Uncle Andrew, “if someone else will go after her, wearing a yellow ring himself and taking two green rings,
one to bring himself back and one to bring her back.”
And now of course Digory saw the trap in which he was caught:
and he stared at Uncle Andrew, saying nothing, with his mouth wide open.
His cheeks had gone very pale.
“I hope,” said Uncle Andrew presently in a very high and mighty voice,
just as if he were a perfect Uncle who had given one a handsome tip and some good advice, “I hope, Digory, you are not given to showing the white feather( 示弱 ).
I should be very sorry to think that anyone of our family had not enough honor and chivalry( 骑士精神 ) to go to the aid of—er—a lady in distress( 危难 ).”
“Oh shut up!” said Digory. “If you had any honor and all that, you’d be going yourself.
But I know you won’t. All right. I see I’ve got to go.
But you are a beast. I suppose you planned the whole thing, so that she’d go without knowing it and then I’d have to go after her.”
“Of course,” said Uncle Andrew with his hateful smile.
“Very well. I’ll go. But there’s one thing I jolly well( 无疑 ) mean to say first.
I didn’t believe in Magic till today. I see now it’s real.
Well if it is, I suppose all the old fairy tales( 童话 ) are more or less true.
And you’re simply a wicked( 恶毒的 ), cruel magician like the ones in the stories.
Well, I’ve never read a story in which people of that sort weren’t paid out in the end, and I bet( 打赌 ) you will be. And serve you right( 罪有应得 ).”
Of all the things Digory had said this was the first that really went home( 切中要害 ).
Uncle Andrew startled and there came over his face a look of such horror( 恐怖 ) that, beast though he was, you could almost feel sorry for him.
But a second later he smoothed it all away and said with a rather forced laugh, “Well, well,
I suppose that is a natural thing for a child to think—brought up among women, as you have been.
Old wives’ tales, eh? I don’t think you need worry about my danger, Digory. Wouldn’t it be better to worry about the danger of your little friend?
She’s been gone some time. If there are any dangers Over There—well, it would be a pity to arrive a moment too late.”
“A lot you care,” said Digory fiercely( 愤怒地 ). “But I’m sick of this jaw( 说教 ). What have I got to do?”
“You really must learn to control that temper( 脾气 ) of yours, my boy,” said Uncle Andrew coolly.
“Otherwise you’ll grow up to be like your Aunt Letty. Now. Attend( 注意 ) to me.”
He got up, put on a pair of gloves, and walked over to the tray( 托盘 ) that contained the rings.
“They only work,” he said, “if they’re actually touching your skin.
Wearing gloves, I can pick them up—like this—and nothing happens.
If you carried one in your pocket nothing would happen: but of course you’d have to be careful not to put your hand in your pocket and touch it by accident.
The moment you touch a yellow ring, you vanish( 消失 ) out of this world.

When you are in the Other Place I expect—of course this hasn’t been tested yet, but I expect—that the moment you touch a green ring you vanish( 消失 ) out of that world and—I expect—reappear( 再出现 ) in this.
Now. I take these two greens and drop them into your right-hand pocket.
Remember very carefully which pocket the greens are in.
G for green and R for right. G.R. you see: which are the first two letters of green.
One for you and one for the little girl. And now you pick up a yellow one for yourself.
I should put it on—on your finger—if I were you. There’ll be less chance of dropping it.”
Digory had almost picked up the yellow ring when he suddenly checked himself.
“Look here,” he said. “What about Mother? Supposing she asks where I am?”
“The sooner you go, the sooner you’ll be back,” said Uncle Andrew cheerfully.
“But you don’t really know whether I can get back.”
Uncle Andrew shrugged( 耸肩 ) his shoulders, walked across to the door, unlocked it, threw it open, and said:
“Oh very well then. Just as you please. Go down and have your dinner.
Leave the little girl to be eaten by wild animals or drowned( 淹死 ) or starved( 饿死 ) in Otherworld or lost there for good, if that’s what you prefer.
It’s all one to me. Perhaps before tea time you’d better drop in on Mrs. Plummer and explain that she’ll never see her daughter again; because you were afraid to put on a ring.”
“By gum,” said Digory, “don’t I just wish I was big enough to punch( 用拳猛击 ) your head!”
Then he buttoned up his coat, took a deep breath, and picked up the ring.
And he thought then, as he always thought afterward( 之后 ) too, that he could not decently( 体面地 ) have done anything else.
Uncle Andrew and his study vanished( 消失 ) instantly.
Then, for a moment, everything became muddled( 混乱的 ).
The next thing Digory knew was that there was a soft green light coming down on him from above, and darkness below.
He didn’t seem to be standing on anything, or sitting, or lying.
Nothing appeared to be touching him. “I believe I’m in water,” said Digory. “Or under water.”
This frightened him for a second, but almost at once he could feel that he was rushing upward.
Then his head suddenly came out into the air and he found himself scrambling( 爬 ) ashore( 向岸上 ), out on to smooth grassy ground at the edge of a pool.
As he rose to his feet he noticed that he was neither dripping( 滴水 ) nor panting( 喘气 ) for breath as anyone would expect after being under water.
His clothes were perfectly dry. He was standing by the edge of a small pool—not more than ten feet from side to side—in a wood.
The trees grew close together and were so leafy that he could get no glimpse( 一瞥 ) of the sky.
All the light was green light that came through the leaves: but there must have been a very strong sun overhead( 在头上方 ), for this green daylight was bright and warm.
It was the quietest wood you could possibly imagine. There were no birds, no insects, no animals, and no wind.
You could almost feel the trees growing.
The pool he had just got out of was not the only pool.
There were dozens of others—a pool every few yards as far as his eyes could reach.
You could almost feel the trees drinking the water up with their roots.
This wood was very much alive.
When he tried to describe it afterward( 之后 ) Digory always said, “It was a rich place: as rich as plumcake( 葡萄干蛋糕 ).”

article_info.previous: Polly神秘地消失，墙上褪色的女士照片引起了Digory的注意，Mrs. Lefay到底是何方神圣？胆小的Uncle Andrew不愿意冒险去营救Polly，那这个重任落在了谁的肩上呢？

article_info.share_words: The trees grew close together and were so leafy that he could get no glimpse of the sky. All the lights was green light that came from through the leaves: but there must have been a very strong sun overhead, for this green daylight was bright and warm.

question.cn: 为什么Uncle Andrew不自己去“另外一个世界”？
question.en: Why didn’t Uncle Andrew go to the “Other World” by himself?

options.cn: 因为他害怕潜在的危险。
options.en: Because he was afraid of the potential dangers.

analysis: 文中当Digory质问为什么Uncle Andrew不自己去那个世界，Uncle Andrew回答道：“A man at my time of life, and in my state of health, to risk the shock and the dangers of being flung suddenly into a different universe? I never heard anything so preposterous in my life!”因此得知Uncle Andrew是害怕危险，因此选A。

question.cn: 根据Uncle Andrew的话，什么颜色的戒指可以带Polly回到现实世界？
question.en: According to Uncle Andrew, what was the color of the ring that could take Polly back?

analysis: 文中Uncle Andrew提到：“I did at last to find out a way of doing the return Journey. The green rings draw you back.”因此选C。

question.en: What was the meaning of G and R？

options.en: G meant Great, and R meant Right.
G meant Green, and R meant Right.
G meant God, and R meant Red.

analysis: 文中Uncle Undrew为了让Digory方便记忆戒指的含义，他提到：“Remember very carefully which pocket the green rings are in. G for green and R for right.” 因此选B。

question.cn: 最后，谁将会带Polly回现实世界？
question.en: At last, Who would take Polly back to the real world?

analysis: 文中提到：“But I know you won’t. All right. I see I’ve got to go. . . very well. I’ll go.”因此Digory决定自己带Polly回到现实世界，因此选B。

question.cn: 当Digory来到另一个世界，树林里只有一个水池吗?
question.en: When Digory went to the Other World, was there just one pool in the woods?

options.en: Yes, there was just one pool.
No, there were dozens of others.

analysis: 文中提到：“The pool he had just got out of was not the only pool. There were dozens of others.”可知树林不止一个水池，因此选B。
